thread.section_title: Small Business | Finance & Small Businesses | News.com.au
thread.title: Credit card inquiry: Big Four bank CEOs may be summoned
thread.title_full: Credit card inquiry: Big Four bank CEOs may be summoned

author: John Rolfe Cost of Living Editor
title: Credit card inquiry: Big Four bank CEOs may be summoned
text:
EXCLUSIVE
THE CEOs of Australia’s largest banks will be dragged before the Senate, if necessary, to explain sky-high credit-card interest rates.
This emerged as more than 10,000 Australian households responded to a rallying cry and joined the Big Debt Switch on its first day of pursuing a better deal on plastic.
News Corp Australia can reveal the Senate economics references committee is prepared to take the unprecedented step of compelling the Big Four bosses to attend if they do not agree to give evidence voluntarily.
“We will never get to the bottom of what has gone on in this industry, in my personal opinion, without getting in the highest officers of Australia’s biggest banks,” said inquiry chairman, Labor’s Sam Dastyari.
“For too long this industry has operated in the dark. The Senate has a responsibility to shine a spotlight it.
“The more evidence I see, the more appalled I am at how consumers have been taken advantage of by this industry,” Senator Dastyari said. More give, less take ... But will he have time to appear? NAB CEO Andrew Thorburn. Picture: Supplied Source: News Corp Australia
Last week, the Reserve Bank of Australia told the inquiry that some interest rates were inexplicably high, while consumer advocacy groups said there was a need to tighten lending criteria and raise minimum repayments.
“It would be unprecedented for the Committee to need to use its compulsion powers; any decision to use those powers would be a matter for the committee,” Senator Dastyari said. “I would hope we won’t need to use our powers in this instance.” Happy to take questions ... He has been in the past. Westpac CEO Brian Hartzer at a Senate inquiry into financial advice. Picture: Supplied Source: News Corp Australia
Inquiry deputy chairman, Liberal Sean Edwards, was equally determined to hear from the banks’ top brass.
“In the interests of getting the full story we will involve all stakeholders,” Senator Edwards said.
News Corp Australia asked the majors whether their leaders would make themselves available.
A CBA spokeswoman said: “Who will appear will depend on a range of factors including availability, but we are committed to sending the most appropriate and available representative.” No, then yes ... Commonwealth Bank CEO Ian Narev initially didn’t make himself available for the financial advice inquiry, then did. What will he do this time? Picture: Supplied Source: News Corp Australia
A NAB spokesman said: “As with any request from parliamentary committees, should NAB be asked to appear it would be considered in due course.”
ANZ and Westpac did not respond.
Meanwhile, the Big Debt Switch campaign is on track to reach its target of 25,000 supporters during the month-long campaign, with more than 10,000 joining the fight on day one.
“This is the hidden household bill,” said Joel Gibson, campaign director at One Big Switch, the consumer network that is leading the battle.
“We want to use that People Power of tens of thousands of Australian households to try and unlock offers that could save people on their credit card debt.”
Numbers of those who signed off on our Big Switch campaign on Day 1 by state:
NSW — 3700
Qld — 2800
Vic — 1500
SA — 800
Tas — 200
WA — 700
NT — 100
ACT — 200
To join the Big Debt Switch, go to the moneysaverHQ section of this website.
* There is no obligation to take up any offer. News Corp Australia and One Big Switch will earn a commission from any accepted deals. News Corp Australia is a shareholder of One Big Switch.
